params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Objectives

To understand the concepts of Open Educational Resources and open licences and their potential usefulness.

What you will do:

  1. Learn about OER and consider what types of open licences might be most appropriate for your materials as they are developed.
  2. Complete a short evaluation.
  3. Search for openly licensed materials for your subject.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Why OER?

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
What are OER?

  • Online textbooks
  • Video-recorded lectures
  • YouTube clips
  • Web-based textual materials designed for independent study
  • Animations and simulations
  • Digital diagrams and graphics
  • PowerPoint slides or PDFs
  • Some course material/lessons if they are packaged as a SCORM (they can be reused)
  • Assessment materials (e.g. tests with automated answers) – must be downloadable

TO BE AN OER, IT MUST BE FREELY AVAILABLE FOR EDUCATIONAL USE
Bates (2019)

metadata.title: Introduction to OER: Knowledge and resources

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Some resources

  • Buchner, N. (2011). A Basic Guide to Open Educational Resources (OER).
  • An academic wishing to openly license their work can refer to OER Africa’s copyright and licensing toolkit to find out about licensing options, applying a licence, and understanding copyright clearance.

metadata.title: Introduction to OER: Knowledge and resources

params.text:
How do I know it is an OER?

A tell-tale sign is the Creative Commons (CC) License

params.alt: MIT has a CC BY-NC-SA license

answers.text: Use components of their course as resources in a traditionally published textbook (C)
Adapt course materials for use in your classes

overallFeedback.feedback: Keep in mind that MIT's OCW is licensed as CC BY-NC-SA. This licence lets others remix, tweak, and build upon their work, non-commercially, and as long as you credit MIT and licence any new creations under the identical terms: CC BY-NC-SA.

params.question: What can you do with MIT's open courseware (OCW)?

choices.question: Which statement best describes the ND right?
answers:
Users cannot change the resource

Users cannot make any copies

Users can change only the images in the resources

Users can make only one copy of the original

overallFeedback.feedback: No Derivatives (ND): You let others copy, distribute, display, and perform only original copies of your work. If they want to modify your work, they must get your permission first.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

choices.question: Which statement best describes the SA right?
answers:
Use the same licence as the original resource

Users must ask permission to use the resource 

Users cannot change the resource

Users cannot make a profit from the resource

overallFeedback.feedback: Share Alike (SA): You let others copy, distribute, display, perform, and modify your work, as long as they distribute any modified work on the same terms. If they want to distribute modified works under other terms, they must get your permission first.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

behaviour.feedbackOnCorrect: The statement is false and in fact the truth is the other way around. When you create a piece of work it is automatically fully copyrighted as 'All Rights Reserved'.
behaviour.feedbackOnWrong: The statement is false and in fact the truth is the other way around. When you create a piece of work it is automatically fully copyrighted as 'All Rights Reserved'.

params.question: True or false? When you create a piece of work it is automatically copyrighted with an open licence.

overallFeedback.feedback: CC BY is the most open of the creative commons licenses and can be paired with any other CC license

params.alt: Option A is CC BY, Option B is CC BY SA, Option C is CC BY NC, Option D is CC BY NC SA, Option E is CC BY ND, and Option F is CC BY NC ND

choices.question: What Creative Commons right is reserved with this symbol?

overallFeedback.feedback: Possibly never seen in Africa, but any currency symbol, including the Yen, can be used to depict 'Non-Commercial'. The dollar, '$', is possibly the most commonly used.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.

params.alt: A circle with a capital Y imposed on two parallel horizontal lines. The image is crossed through, indicating that it is not applicable

choices.question: Identify which right the author has reserved when using this CC symbol.

overallFeedback.feedback: All CC licences require that others who use your work in any way must give you credit (attribution) the way you request, but not in a way that suggests you endorse them or their use

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.

choices.question: Creative Commons Zero licence is equivalent to ...

overallFeedback.feedback: CC0: The work is in the public domain. The author has waived all of his or her rights to the work worldwide under copyright law.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.

choices.question: Which licences do not allow re-purposing or adaptation?
answers:
E and F

C and F

A and B

D and F

overallFeedback.feedback: Remember that licences that contain ND (No Derivatives) do not permit modifications to the original resource.

params.alt: Option A is CC BY, Option B is CC BY SA, Option C is CC BY NC, Option D is CC BY NC SA, Option E is CC BY ND, and Option F is CC BY NC ND

choices.question: Which licences prohibit use of the resource in new works that will be fully copyrighted?
answers:
B and D

C and F

B and F

D and F

overallFeedback.feedback: Remember that licences that contain SA (Share-Alike) require the new work, or derivative, to have exactly the same licence. A published fully copyrighted work would need to change the licence.

params.text: Activity: Complete the Google Advanced Search process

params.taskDescription: Arrange the steps for Google Advanced Search in the correct order
params.resetDropDescription: Are you sure you want to reset this drop zone?
params.a11yCheck: Check the answers. The responses will be marked as correct, incorrect, or unanswered.
params.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
params.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.
params.textField:
Step 1: Go to *www.google.com/advanced_search\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!* and *Enter your search term\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!* 
Step 2:*Scroll down to usage rights, and choose the most open licence (free to use, share or modify, even commercially)\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!* then *Click the Advanced Search button\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!*
Step 3:*Choose one of the results discovered, and check that it does indeed have an open licence (scroll down the page to check)\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!*
Step 4:*Download the OER (if appropriate)\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!*

metadata.title: Place the process of searching for an OER in Google Advanced Search in the correct order
metadata.extraTitle: Place the process of searching for an OER in Google Advanced Search in the correct order

elements.solution:
Summary of the Google Advanced Search process:

  1. Go to www.google.com/advanced_search
  2. Enter your search term
  3. Go to usage rights, and choose the most open licence (free to use, share or modify, even commercially)
  4. Click the Advanced Search button.
  5. Choose one of the results discovered, and check that it does indeed have an open licence (scroll down the page to check).
  6. Download the OER (if appropriate)

metadata.extraTitle: Using Creative Commons Filters on Popular Platforms

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Activity: Complete the YouTube search process

params.taskDescription: Arrange the steps for the YouTube OER search in the correct order
params.resetDropDescription: Are you sure you want to reset this drop zone?
params.a11yCheck: Check the answers. The responses will be marked as correct, incorrect, or unanswered.
params.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
params.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.
params.textField:
Step 1: Go to YouTube.com and *Enter your search term\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!* 
Step 2:Click on *Filters\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!* and choose the *Creative Commons\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!* option, not the *CC\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!*, under the *Features\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!* column
Step 3: Click on a video of your choice, paying attention to its date, duration and number of views, and double check what type of Creative Commons license is applicable to your selection by clicking on *Show More\+Correct!\-Incorrect, try again!* beneath the video.

metadata.title: Place the process of searching for an OER in YouTube in the correct order
metadata.extraTitle: Place the process of searching for an OER in YouTube in the correct order

elements.solution:
Summary of the YouTube search process:

  • Go to YouTube
  • Enter your search term
  • Click on FILTERS, and choose the Creative Commons (not CC) in the FEATURES column.
  • Click on a video of your choice and check that it does indeed have a Creative Commons licence (scroll down and click SHOW MORE to check).

params.text:
Useful sites to get started with OER

  • OER Africa https://www.oerafrica.org/
  • Open Professionals Education Network (provides a broad guide of where to find different types of OER) https://open4us.org/find-oer/
  • MERLOT http://www.merlot.org/
  • OER Commons https://www.oercommons.org/
  • OpenVerse (media) https://wordpress.org/openverse/?referrer=creativecommons.org 
  • Unisa Library guides https://libguides.unisa.ac.za/OpenEducationalResources
  • Open Text Books https://open.umn.edu/opentextbooks

metadata.title: Introduction to OER: Knowledge and resources

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
How do I reference OER in publications?

In general, when referencing an OER in an article/dissertation/thesis to be published, you will follow the same process as when referencing a website (This example is APA style):

Gitman, L.J. et al. (19 September 2018). Using supply chain management to increase efficiency and customer satisfaction. OpenStax by Rice University. Retrieved 6 April 2022, from https://openstax.org/books/introduction-business/pages/12-4-using-supply-chain-management-to-increase-efficiency-and-customer-satisfaction. 

  • Parenthetical citation: (Gitman et al, 2021)
  • Narrative citation: Gitman et al (2021)

metadata.title: Introduction to OER: Knowledge and resources

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
How do I reference OER digitally?

Make your own attribution for your OER in the digital space:

Open Attribution Builder: https://www.openwa.org/attrib-builder/

  • "Global trends", eLearning Support Initiative, University of Minnesota is licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0
  • "Using supply chain management to increase efficiency and customer satisfaction" by Gitman, LJ, McDaniel, C, Shah, A, Reece, M, Koffel, L, Talsma, B & Hyatt, JC, OpenStax, Rice University is licensed under CC BY 4.0
